Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Political Incorporation of Asian Americans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Asian Americans constitute the United States' fastest growing immigrant population relative to its preexisting size. As this population expands, we need to understand more about how these new immigrants become politically integrated into United States society. We know that social groups that succeed in terms of educational attainment and earnings typically have high levels of political participation. What is most perplexing about Asian Americans is that, despite their relative economic and educational success, they lag behind other racial groups in voter turnout. The most recent studies of this question have not produced adequate answers. This project will investigate the causes for lower Asian American voter turnout as well as provide a more detailed understanding of how Asian Americans understand and define participation in the public sphere. This latter aspect is important given that much of the potential for greater civic inclusion lies in the recognition of the diverse but often overlooked extra-institutional forms of political engagement more common among recent immigrants. This project will provide political parties and our society generally with information useful in promoting greater participation in the political process by facilitating greater engagement of civically-minded citizens, thus strengthening our democracy.


This mixed-methods project will combine quantitative analysis of existing data sets with in-depth interviews. The project will use The Current Population Survey between 2000 and 2014 to verify prior research concerning patterns of voter turnout among Asian Americans. The project will also analyze the 2016 National Asian American Survey to test hypotheses regarding the mechanisms behind recent voter patterns, including forms of political participation other than actual voting. Finally, the project will conduct 90 interviews in a large city with subgroups of Asian Americans to capture these groups' perspectives on their political engagement and experiences in the public sphere. After the interviews are transcribed, qualitative coding will produce common themes and concepts. Atlas.ti will be used to organize, manage and analyze the data. Findings from the project will show both overall patterns and subgroup differences in the motivations for political participation among Asian Americans, and test hypotheses regarding the mechanisms behind these patterns. Findings will inform theories in both sociology and political science related to political participation, especially the role of resources in motivating such participation. Findings will also speak to sociological theories regarding ethnic group assimilation to better understand why Asian Americans assimilate readily socio-economically, but less readily politically. The findings will also speak to sociological theories regarding the role of culture in patterning public sphere behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated potential barriers to Asian American political participation (voting and registration) and the alternative forms of civic engagement within these communities. Asian Americans, despite their relatively high levels of income and education, demonstrate lower voter turnout rates than Whites, Latinos, and Blacks. This gap persists even when considering income, education, years lived in the U.S., and immigrant generation. The puzzle of the case of Asian American voting is therefore focused on why the predominant predictors of voting for the general population?income, education, and occupational status?do not seem to resolve this voting turnout gap.

In order to address this question, project funding was provided to conduct interviews with Asian Americans of Japanese, Chinese, and Indian heritage in the greater Los Angeles metropolitan area. Funds went toward travel and lodging for the interviewer and $20 gift cards as a form of time compensation for interviewees. A total of 84 interviews were conducted at multiple sites, split into 24 Japanese, 34 Chinese, and 26 Indian heritage interviewees. Interview questions were designed to unpack the reasoning for Asian American interviewees? political behaviors in a number of ways; by considering their identities and the feelings of social position they communicate, by identifying their civic tool kits and practical know-how that shapes their capacity to participate, by discussing their general disposition towards politic participation such as its risks and practical importance, and, finally, by considering the impact of the social network of their ethnic community on their consideration to participate.

This study identified two potentially key explanations for Asian American voting behavior that merit further investigation. First, national origin has a significant impact on political participation because the skills and attitudes towards civic engagement are formed in the sending country. These orientations towards political participation are highly durable in adulthood and are likely to shape feelings about government corruption, the risks involved in political activity, and the efficacy of personal political action even when individuals have relocated to an entirely different political regime. Among those from mainland China, in contrast to those from Hong Kong and Taiwan, there was skepticism that any political action on their part would matter.  Among the Indians who were merchants, in contrast to professionals, skepticism was rooted in the corruption they witnessed in their homeland.  Second, given that the priority of most immigrants is initial survival, political participation is delayed across generations unless political action is deemed necessary for survival. Another framing of this phenomenon is that a group?s immediate experiences with governmental institutions in the U.S. matter. Historically Japanese Americans, similar to Latinos today, had very negative experiences, e.g., detainment and incarceration. Faced with such threats, political mobilization becomes a prerequisite to pursuing the American dream.

This project advances our theoretical understanding of political participation and the means by which immigrants are politically integrated. Although the predominant theory of political participation consistently finds socioeconomic status as the strongest predictor of political participation, in the case of immigrants these are better framed as important but not sufficient conditions to independently produce high levels of formal institutional engagement. This research contributes to our understanding of some necessary conditions for political participation by drawing from the concepts of civic habitus?the generalized disposition toward public participation?and civic skills. For individuals to engage in politics requires both a disposition that generates a sense of efficacy and low risk, and a tool kit of skills that provide the know-how required to participate. These concepts better capture the reason national origin exhibits such a strong effect on the variation in Asian Americans? willingness to engage and interest in politics.

The findings of this project can be practically applied by groups wishing to mobilize Asian Americans for greater collective action and can be used to inform public servants in their efforts to build bridges between local government service and immigrant communities. For both groups, focus should be directed towards developing civic skills, lowering the perceived risk of participation, and increasing individuals? sense of efficacy in political action.
